_header: God against nature three wonders hath wrought
Note:
Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 476.
Subjects: carols, Nativity; religious instruction; Incarnation, mystery of
_description: A theological carol about the Incarnation — seven 9-line stanzas plus burden: ‘By reason of two & poore of one / This tyme god & man was set at one’

BLCottVesAXXV.First Lines:
God against nature thre wonders haith wroughtFirst of the vile
                    earthe mad man without man…
BLCottVesAXXV.Last Lines:
…And cease ther strifeFor marie was maden widowe and
                    wife
BLCottVesAXXV.Editions:
Wright,  Thomas,
                        ed.  
             Specimens of Old Christmas Carols, etc.
Percy Society
         4. London: T. Richard, 1841: 41-4.
Böddeker,  Karl. 
             “Englische Lieder und Balladen aus dem 16. Jahrhundert.” 
             Jahrbuch für romanische und englische Sprache- und
                Literatur
         14 (or n.f. 2) (1875): 81-105 [933]: 2.98.
Greene,  Richard Leighton. 
             The Early English Carols.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1935; 2nd ed., rev., Oxford: Clarendon,
            1977: 60-2; 1977, 50-1.

TokyoTak6.First Lines:
God ageynst nature iij thyngys hath wroughtffurst of the vyle erth
                    made man without man…
TokyoTak6.Last Lines:
…Thanke we hyme thaneThat thus lefte angell and sauyde
                    mane
TokyoTak6.Note:
Added by a sixteenth-century hand; Burden and first two stanzas only;
                    begins with introductory 4-line stanza abab, ‘Here begynneth a lamentable
                    complaint’; then title ‘A carolle’ and then a couplet burden,
                    ‘By resone of ij and power of one / This tyme god and man were sett at
                    one’; then the first two verses in two 9-line stanzas, rhyming
                    ababbccdd.
TokyoTak6.Attributed Title:
In principio si placet (by scribe, following explicit to preceding
                    work)
TokyoTak6.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.

                ab. 1530.”
